III.

BACKGROUND

Sri Lanka has traditionally been a rural country with a society based on village life and an
3.
economy based on agriculture. This has changed somewhat over the last two decades with the
contribution  of  agriculture  to  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  declining  from  30.3  percent  in
1978  to  19.7  percent  in  2000,  and  the  contribution  of  the  service  sector  increasing  from  44.4
percent  to  54.6  percent  during  the  same  period.2  These  figures  indicate  an  increasing  trend
toward  urbanization.  However,  almost  all  urbanization  has  tended  to  concentrate  in  Western
Province  and,  more  specifically,  in  and  around  greater  Colombo.    Most  other  areas  have
continued  to  be  very  much  rural  oriented  with  economic  activity  predominantly  focused  on
agriculture,  livestock,  fisheries,  and  forestry.  Statistics  also  show  that  the  level  of  poverty  by
province is proportionate to the rural share of its population. Thus, in Western Province where 50
percent of the population is rural, the poverty level is 23 percent, whereas in Southern Province,
80 percent of the population is rural and the poverty level is about 40 percent.3 This link of rural
areas  to  poverty  is  a  direct  result  of  the  inefficient  and  unproductive  nature  of  much  of  the
agriculture  sector  upon  which  the  rural  areas  and  rural  populations  are  dependent.  Agricultural
growth has remained low for many reasons, including uneconomic landholding size; restrictions

Southern Province

Southern  Province  comprises  three  districts:  Galle,  Hambantota,  and  Matara;  and
5.
stretches along the southern coast of Sri Lanka, extending 65 kilometers (km) inland at its widest
point.  It has a gross area of 554,200 hectares (ha) and is about 250 km long from the town of
Bentota in the west to Yala National Park in the east. The total population of the province is about
2.4 million4 of which about 80 percent are considered rural and about 40 percent poor, according
to the national poverty line.

6.
Land  forms  range  from  flat  coastal  plains  in  the  south  to  hills  in  the  north;  the  climate
ranges from wet and humid in the west to dry and arid in the east.  As a result, Southern Province
covers a wide range of natural ecosystems, and the land and water use patterns as well as the
agricultural cropping systems are extremely varied. These range from forests and tea estates in
rolling  upland  country  in  the  north  and  east,  through  low-lying  coconut  and  paddy  areas  in  the
wetter coastal plains, to semiarid lowland plains in the eastern dry zone. The latter are suitable
only for subsistence shifting cultivation or livestock production. Being a coastal province, fisheries
and fish production are also an important resource use.

Agriculture, the predominant economic activity, contributes about 30 percent of provincial
7.
GDP  and  about  48  percent  of  employment.  However,  the  importance  of  agriculture  as  an
employer  varies  across  the  province  and  increases  considerably  in  the  east;  36  percent  of  the
population in Galle is dependent on agriculture as compared with 54 percent in Hambantota. The
major  export  crops  grown  in  the  region  include  tea  (43,000  ha),  rubber  (17,000  ha),  coconut
(46,000  ha),  cinnamon  (19,000  ha),  rice  (76,000  ha),  banana  (11,000  ha),  and  jackfruit  (11,000
ha). The province produces 33 percent of Sri Lanka’s tea and 75 percent of the world’s cinnamon.
In  1999/2000,  the  combined  value  of  annual  and  perennial  farm  production  in  the  region  was
estimated at SLRs25 billion. Most of the tea is grown efficiently, but considerable scope exists for
intercropping and value addition in coconut areas.

8.
Industrial growth in the region has been sparse and contributes only about 10 percent to
the  provincial  GDP  and  13  percent  to  employment.5  One  of  the  main  reasons  is  that  Western

9.
As  with  the  area’s  geographical  characteristics,  socioeconomic  characteristics  are  also
varied. Although the human development indicators in Southern Province are relatively high,6 the
consumption poverty levels remain high, indicating a lack of economic opportunities in the region.
The economy is dominated by agriculture, and the poverty originates both from low productivity in
agriculture, and more importantly, the sluggish growth of the nonfarm sector. At the same time,
the uneconomic size of landholding requires people to engage in off-farm employment to reduce
vulnerability.7 This currently accounts for 15-20 percent of total income among the lowest quintile.
The 1982 census data places the average size of landholding in the province at 0.6 ha, with only
about  25  percent  of  households  having  farmlands  of  greater  than  0.8  ha.  Landholdings  of  this
size would normally support little more than subsistence activities.8

10. 
This situation is compounded by high levels of unemployment rates and lack of economic
opportunities available to a considerable segment of the population. The unemployment rate for
the province was 14 percent, compared with the national unemployment rate of 11 percent. The
high  unemployment  rate,  especially  among  the  youth  (33  percent),  and  the  relatively  low
involvement  of  women  in  the  formal  economy  are  two  major  social  problems  in  the  province.
National  data  indicates  that  unemployment  levels  among  women  in  the  labor  force  have  been
consistently higher than among men throughout the 1990s and the situation in Southern Province
is similar.9 Increasing youth and female unemployment, despite the high overall school enrollment
rate  of  73  percent,  is  resulting  in  growing  levels  of  social  dissatisfaction  among  this  potentially
productive segment of the population and is emerging as major Government concern.

This situation can be redressed if the economy of Southern Province can be uplifted from
11.
its  prevailing  subsistence-based  production  patterns  to  one  based  on  commercially  focused
productive activities. Considerable development assistance has been directed to the province in
the last two decades, and a series of irrigation, agriculture, and rural development projects have
been  supported  by  ADB  and  other  development  agencies.  These  have  assisted  in  building  up
infrastructure,  and  in  particular,  expanding  the  irrigated  areas  in  the  region  and  promoting  crop
diversification,  but  the  region  continues  to  remain  disadvantaged.  The  last  in  the  series  of  ADB
rural development support initiatives to the region was the Southern Province Rural Development
Project  (SPRDP),10  which  was  implemented  between  1992  and  2000.  Planned  investments  in
Southern Province include the ADB-financed Southern Transport Development Project, which is
to  construct  a  highway  from  Colombo  to  Matara,  at  the  center  of  the  province.  This  highway,
when completed, will cut the travel time between the two cities from the present four to five hours
to about one and a half hours, and result in a major economic boost for the region.

as  transport,  agriculture  input  supply,  and  other  small  industries.  The  Government  policy
framework recognizes that facilitating MSMEs is critical to achieving the objectives of expanding
the country’s industrial base, efficiently adding value to the country’s resource endowments, and

intends  to  undertake  future  rural  development  efforts  through  REAPs,  reflecting  a  move  away
from a top-down, public sector-led approach to one that is decentralized and includes the private
sector  as  a  partner  to  stimulate  economic  growth.  The  proposed  Project  will  be  one  of  the  first
major projects designed to operationalize this new strategy.

B.  

Objective and Scope

35.
The  Project's  objective  is  to  support  the  Government’s  efforts  to  accelerate  economic
growth  and  create  additional  income  and  employment  opportunities  in  Southern  Province.  This
will be accomplished by (i) establishing and expanding MSMEs in agriculture-related sectors; (ii)
providing  and  maintaining  key  economic  infrastructure;  and  (iii)  enhancing  public  and  private
sector  capacities  to  facilitate,  support,  and  sustain  the  process  of  economic  growth.  Special
emphasis  will  be  placed  on  unemployed  youth  and  women  with  the  objective  of  providing  them
with productive and sustainable income and employment opportunities.

36.
The Project comprises two interrelated parts that will be implemented simultaneously. Part
I  is  intended  to  stimulate  economic  activity  in  the  region  and  includes  support  to  (i)  enterprise
development services (EDS); and (ii) a credit line for financing term loans. Part II is intended to
build  an  enabling  environment  for  economic  growth  and  includes  support  for  (i)  providing  rural
infrastructure, particularly rural roads and markets; (ii) enhancing technical and financial capacity

1.

Part I  Stimulating Economic Growth

37.
The  major  part  of  this  component  will  be  a  credit  line  aimed  at  promoting  MSMEs  in
Southern Province. Recognizing that a credit line by itself is not sufficient to stimulate economic
innovation, the Project will contract private advisory services to provide agricultural producers and
entrepreneurs  a  link  to  new  technologies,  marketing  channels,  technical  and  managerial  skills,
financial  services,  and  key  information.  The  focus  of  this  component  is  on  stimulating  private
sector  activity  and  building  up  sustainable  enterprise  support  services.  Part  I  has  two
components: advisory services to guide entrepreneurs and a credit line to enable investment.

a.

Enterprise Development Services

38.
Considerable  potential  exists  in  Southern  Province  for  a  wide  variety  of  economic
enterprises  in  rural  areas,  including  moving  from  traditional  low-value  crops  to  high-value
production  and  to  secondary  value-adding  activities  (para.  12).  However,  the  majority  of  small
agriculture producers and entrepreneurs lack technical and market information, skills, access to
financial services, and market linkages.33 They need assistance and advice on possible economic
ventures, with initial project design, appraisal, and costing; technical and financial management;
identification and provision of technologies; and identification of potential markets, and sources of
training and information. On the other hand, opportunities for larger enterprises can be facilitated
by  improving  linkages  with  producers,  technology,  and  financial  services.  The  Project  will
therefore support the establishment and expansion of a range of professional EDS in the province
to  enable  producers  and  entrepreneurs  to  access  necessary  services,  products,  market
information, and contacts in a sustainable manner.

39.
Several  private  sector  and  NGO  agencies  in  the  country  have,  over  the  last  few  years,
developed  core  competencies  in  this  field.  For  example,  at  the  national  level,  the  National
Agribusiness Council supports major agribusinesses with technology and marketing linkages, and
at the local level, SEEDS, an NGO, provides advice to microentrepreneurs. Some EDS initiatives
have also been supported in Southern Province by NGOs, development agencies, and a district
chamber  of  commerce  (Hambantota).  But  the  work  thus  far,  has  largely  been  dependent  on
external/Government  funding or has remained limited to certain kinds of clients (various NGOs
are  providing  support  to  very  poor  women  for  microenterprises).  The  Project  therefore  aims  to
facilitate the development and expansion of a range of enterprise service providers, build synergy
among  them  to  access  and  share  information,  and  create  an  environment  for  competitive  and
costed services.

40.
A primary objective of this component will be to provide training and guidance to potential
participants in the Project’s credit component. Equally important will be to set up and strengthen
enterprise development advisory units and enterprise information services, possibly patterned on
the  Hambantota  District  chambers  of  commerce.    Other  activities  to  be  undertaken  under  this
component will include an inventory of potential agribusiness opportunities within the project area;
identification of markets and technology linkages for new and existing products; direct provision of
advice for larger business proposals; provision of technical support and information linkages for
EDS providers taking part in the Project; and direct advisory support to special lending programs
of  financing  institutions  participating  in  the  credit  line.  Entrepreneur  training  will  be  substantially
improved  by  incorporating  modules  on  market  linkages,  value  addition,  and  enhanced
competencies (innovation, risk taking, quality, etc.)  The component will operate on the basis of
providing  the  full  range  of  services  to  the  new  and  existing  enterprises  to  enhance  viable
investments and improve the technical and managerial efficiency of the sector.

productive employment opportunities.

42.
To achieve this, a credit line will be provided to finance medium- and long-term investment
needs of about 1,500 SMEs and about 7,000 microenterprises.  Small enterprises are defined as
those  with  fixed  assets,  excluding  land  and  buildings,  of  not  more  than  SLRs7  million  on
completion  of  the  subproject.  Microenterprises  are  defined  as  those  having  fixed  assets,
excluding land and buildings, of not more than SLRs500,000 on completion of the subproject. The
ADB  credit  line  will  support  70  percent  of  the  total  subproject  cost.  The  PFIs  will  contribute  10
percent and the balance will be the contribution of the suborrower.

43.
In  the  absence  of  a  market-driven  benchmark  interest  rate  for  long-term  investments  in
the country (para. 41), the Project will use the AWDR as the anchor for relending to the PFIs. The
AWDR, determined by CBSL on a monthly basis, captures an element of medium-term interest
rates, largely reflects the average weighted costs of resources available in the banking system,
and is therefore considered an appropriate benchmark.34 The National Development Bank (NDB)
will  serve  as  the  apex  agency  for  channeling  the  credit  line  and,  as  done  for  other  small  and
microenterprise  projects,  it  will  be  given  a  1  percent  spread  for  this  purpose.  The  1  percent
spread  to  NDB  will  be  used,  among  others,  to  strengthen  the  PFIs'  capacity,  especially  the
NGOs,  to  appraise  and  process  medium-  and  long-term  loans  to  the  MSMEs  on  a  sustainable
basis.  The  Government  will  bear  the  foreign  exchange  risk  from  the  difference  between  the
AWDR minus the 1 percent margin to NDB and the borrowing cost.

2.

Part II  Sustaining the Enabling Environment

44. 
Part  II  is  designed  to  enable  the  provincial  council  and  the  pradeshiya  sabhas (the  key
development agencies in the decentralized setup) to promote and sustain rural economic growth.
The  major  part  of  this  component  will  be  the  provision  of  critical  rural  infrastructure  and  the
development of institutional capacity in local governments to maintain it.

45. 
In the course of the past decade, a large amount of rural infrastructure has been built or
upgraded  within  Southern  Province  through  a  series  of  externally  funded  projects,  including  the
SPRDP  and  IRDPs  in  Matara  and  Hambantota.  While  the  provision  of  these  facilities  has  had
positive impacts on the economic and welfare status of the population of the province, a serious
problem has emerged. All of this infrastructure, as well as the previously existing infrastructure,
needs  to  be  maintained,  but  funds  available  to  the  provincial  government  and  the  pradeshiya
sabhas  are  insufficient.  As  a  result,  much  of  the  province's  rural  infrastructure  is  deteriorating,

a. 

Capacity Building for Pradeshiya Sabhas to Maintain Rural Roads

Southern  Province  has  about  7,000  km  of  rural  access  roads.  Maintenance  funds  are
48.
available from many sources but are generally sufficient to maintain only about 25 percent of the
roads. In addition to inadequacy of funding, most pradeshiya sabhas are often not aware of the
need for or mechanisms of routine infrastructure maintenance, nor are their limited technical staff
familiar  with  cost-effective  and  technically  sound  maintenance  techniques.  Yet  rural  roads  must
be  kept  passable  since  they  are  the  basis  for  the  efficient  functioning  of  the  rural  economy.
Without  such  roads,  farmers  either  will  have  no  access  to  markets  or  will  have  to  pay  high
transport  costs  to  reach  them.  Moreover,  poor  road  conditions  deter  farmers  from  producing
commodities  such  as  fruits,  vegetables,  and  livestock  products  that  could  provide  high  returns.
This  component  has  thus  been  designed  to  help  overcome  some  of  the  constraints  facing
pradeshiya  sabhas  that  have  been  charged  with  responsibility  for  maintaining  rural  roads  in  a
passable condition.

49.
The first stage in this activity will involve demonstrating to the pradeshiya sabhas and their
technical  staff  the  best  practices  in  rural  road  maintenance.To  do  this,  one  rural  access  road
approximately  1  km  in  length  will  be  developed  as  a  demonstration  road  in  each  pradeshiya
sabha.  These roads will be used to show (i) optimum design standards for rural roads, and (ii)
low-cost  measures  that  can  be  taken  to  reduce  maintenance  requirements  and  costs.    Such
measures  include  proper  surface  and  side  drainage,  proper  compaction,  proper  shaping,  and
timely pothole filling. These demonstrations will be the basis for the standards set for contractors
undertaking maintenance for the pradeshiya sabha and will also serve as examples to any private
individuals  or  village  communities  that  wish  to  voluntarily  undertake  maintenance  activities.
Conducting these demonstrations will also serve as a technical upgrading exercise for pradeshiya
sabha technical staff.

50.
Upon  completion  of  the  demonstration  roads,  the  pradeshiya  sabhas  will  be  given  the
opportunity  to  identify  and  propose  key  rural  roads,  in  accordance  with  established  selection
criteria  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  initial  upgrading  and  preventive  maintenance  works,  and  then  to
receive transitional funding from the Project for maintenance, as they mobilize their own budget
for maintenance funding. About 30 km of the most important roads will be taken up for transitional

scale  such  that  by  the  end  of  the  Project,  maintenance  funding  will  be  provided  entirely  by  the

 b.

Market Upgrading and Improvement

52.
The  92  formal  markets  in  Southern  Province  and  their  environs  provide  the  foremost
producer  marketing  channel  for  fresh  produce,  and  constitute  accumulation  points  for  the
transport of produce to other parts of the country. Moreover market fees constitute a major part of
the  self-generated  income  of  the  pradeshiya  sabhas.  (Other  revenue  sources  include  limited
grants from the national and provincial governments, and local levies and taxes imposed by local
governments).

53.
Most  markets  in  the  project  area  are  poorly  developed  and  poorly  maintained,  largely
because of poor management. Yet they represent the most important source of direct revenue for
the  pradeshiya  sabhas;  this  could  be  substantially  increased  if  these  markets  were  better
developed  and  better  managed.  Once  markets  are  improved  with  better  facilities  and  or
expanded,  the  pradeshiya  sabhas  could  charge  higher  fees  and  accommodate  more  lessees,
thereby  enhancing  revenues  for  the  maintenance  of  all  infrastructure,  including  roads,  in  their
jurisdiction.

54.
According to studies undertaken by SPC, the cost of improvements required for a number
of markets studied, varies from about $50,000 to about $400,000. The Project will thus support
market development and upgrading by providing financing for market improvement, which may be
drawn upon by a pradeshiya sabha that meets the selection criteria satisfactory to SPC and ADB,
and is willing to commit to improved O&M practices and continued maintenance. Selection criteria
for markets to be taken up by the Project are given in Appendix 6.

55.
Participation  in  the  Project  will  be  closely  linked  with  the  pradeshiya  sabha  drawing  up
plans  for  the  sustainable  operation  of  the  market  through  adequate  levels  of  user  fees  and
management of the facilities by a market traders association, rather than through the tendering of
fee collection on an annual basis as is currently the practice. Market designs will be finalized in
consultation  with  market  users.  Consulting  services  will  be  provided  to  help  design  market
upgrading that best meets the needs of market users (and potential future commercial ventures).
On  the  basis  of  a  notional  average  upgrading  cost  of  $100,000  per  market,  $2.0  million  will  be
provided to cover 20 markets under this component.

A.

Economic and Financial Analyses

118. Economic  and  financial  analyses  have  been  undertaken  for  two  components:  (i)  the

investments that entrepreneurs may undertake with credit and advisory services provided by the
Project.  Plans are to improve 1,049 km (roughly 29 km per pradeshiya sabha) of economically
important  gravel  roads  into  a  condition  in  which  they  are  maintainable  by  local  government
authorities. A total of 20 markets will also be upgraded, both to improve the level of services to
traders  and  consumers  and  to  enhance  the  revenue  that  pradeshiya  sabhas  glean  from  such
markets. The indicative enterprises include floriculture for export, fruit, a poultry hatchery, broiler
production,  ornamental  fish,  fish  culture,  a  rice  mill,  and  a  shoe  manufacture.    During  the  six
years of project implementation, approximately 8,000–10,000 of such enterprises are expected to
emerge, encouraged by project assistance including financing, marketing services, TA, and other
business  management  services.    Detailed  results  of  the  economic  and  financial  analyses  are
summarized in Appendix 15.

1. 

Economic Justification

119.
The  economic  analysis  adopted  a  world  price  numeraire  and  used  values  expressed  in
constant  2001  prices.    Economic  costs  were  derived  from  financial  cost  data,  and  nontraded
goods and services were converted to economic values using a standard conversion factor of 0.9
and a shadow wage rate of 0.75.  Enhanced benefits of induced demand that might be expected
from the completion of the ADB-financed Southern Transport Corridor Project and the Southern
Road Improvement Project have been excluded from project benefits.

120. Quantifiable  benefits  of  gravel  rural  roads  include  the  value  of  time  savings  to  travelers,
decreased  vehicle  operating  costs,  and  a  decrease  in  the  amount  of  spoilage  of  agricultural
produce transported on the roads.  The economic internal rate of return of the roads is 23 percent
and  the  economic  net  present  value  is  SLRs470  million.    Sensitivity  analyses  for  decreases  in
benefits and increase in costs indicates that these results are quite robust.  Care must, of course,
be paid to the level of maintenance actually done, as inadequate maintenance could eventually
decrease  road  services  to  their  without-project  level.  The  Project  will  provide  substantial  TA  to
ensure that road improvements result in maintainable roads and to help local authorities develop
financial systems that will enable them to fulfill all of their maintenance responsibilities.

121. Rural  markets  comprise  the  most  important  marketing  channel  for  farm  produce  in  the

C.

Social Dimensions and Impact on Poverty

127.
The  Project  will  address  the  key  poverty  issue  of  lack  of  employment  opportunities  for
vulnerable  groups,  most  of  who  are  currently  engaged  in  agriculture  and  related  activities.  The
Project  will  also  generate  new  economic  opportunities  for  marginalized  groups,  such  as
communities engaged in fishing, coconut workers, urban slum dwellers, etc. Part I of the Project will
support  micro  and  small  enterprises,  and  enable  expansion  of  term  credit  facilities  to  those  who
currently  have  limited  access  to  it.  As  microenterprises  are  dominated  by  the  economically
weaker sections of society, especially women, it will improve women’s livelihood and directly and
indirectly  benefit  the  poor.40  In  addition,  the  EDS  will  help  upgrade  technology  and  market
linkages,  and  generate  employment  for  about  25,000  persons.41  The  enterprise  development
assistance  and  awareness  building  efforts  of  the  Project  for  youth  will  contribute  to  making  the
necessary transitional process easier for both youth and local business communities to utilize the
emerging opportunities. Because ADB funds are for a long term, the PFIs will also be strengthened
financially by reducing their duration- and interest-variation risks and improving fund management.
In  the  process,  the  capacity  of  NGO-PFIs  to  carry  out  sustainable  and  cost-effective  lending  to
microenterprises will be enhanced and permanent access provided to the poor in rural areas.

The  social  impact  of  Part  II  will  be  positive  as  it  will  facilitate  an  interface  between
128.
producers and markets. By keeping rural roads in an operable condition the component will help
provide the infrastructure needed for the rural population to access health and sanitation benefits,
education, as well as product marketing facilities. Moreover, improved markets will allow the local
population  access  to  an  increased  range  of  productive  activities  as  well  as  to  better  quality
produce at lower prices.

129. Not  undertaking  the  component,  on  the  other  hand,  could  lead  to  serious  social
deprivation as the existing access to services and economic opportunities will be lost.  A further
positive  social  aspect  of  the  component  is  that  it  will  generate  employment  through  road
maintenance activities and lead to a higher level of skills among the rural population.  An offshoot
of  the  component  may  be  better  cooperation  among  rural  residents  as  they  form  beneficiary
groups to help share the burden of the pradeshiya sabhas for road maintenance.  Some voluntary
rural  road  maintenance  activities  have  already  taken  place  within  Southern  Province  and  this
component will help them to continue more effectively and efficiently.

First,  the  REAP  approach  envisages  a  private  sector-led  and  decentralized  mode  of
operation under which a new structure of roles and responsibilities has to necessarily evolve for
MPI  and  SPC.  This  would  imply  new  capacity  to  discharge  new  responsibilities  and  attitudinal
shifts  from  what  has  thus  far  characterized  the  two  agencies.  The  Project  provides  adequate
support  to  enable  the  participating  public  sector  agencies  to  make  this  transition,  but  any

period of one year is built into project implementation and close monitoring of project is planned
during the first year.

132.  Second,  the  Project  will  entail  an  innovative  partnership  between  SPC,  and  private-  and
NGO-operated  EDS.  Initiating  and  operating  this  partnership  will  have  risks.  As  a  first  step,  the
dialogue process with MPI, SPC, and potential private sector partners was initiated during project
processing  and  joint  workshops  organized.  To  minimize  risks  and  ensure  clear  delineation  of
operational  modalities,  the  lead  EDS  agency  is  housed  in  the  PMO  and  will  function  as  the
technical support unit of the public sector.

133.
Third,  local  entrepreneurs  are  unable  to  identify  adequate  profitable  opportunities  for
investment  in  the  region.  The  project  design  therefore  includes  initial  investment  surveys,
identification  of  investment  opportunities,  and  canvassing  of  potential  entrepreneurs  during  the
first  year.  The  investigation  of  possible  private  sector  partners  in  the  Project  has  focused  on
agencies  that  have  developed  sufficient  links  with  industry  and  market  to  make  the  necessary
linkages with the new enterprises.

134.  Fourth,  the  Project  is  designed  against  the  backdrop  of  several  new  developments  that
will  enhance  the  potential  for  economic  growth  in  Southern  Province.  These  include  projects
financed by ADB, such as the Southern Transport Development Project, and other development
partners.  If  completion  of  any  of  these  projects  or  accrual  of  benefits  is  delayed,  the  overall
potential  benefit  generated  by  the  proposed  Project  will  be  reduced.  But,  this  eventuality  has
been considered and due care taken in testing the economic viability of the Project (only benefits
directly  generated  by  project  activities  have  been  calculated  and  those  emanating  from  other
projects have been ignored). The projected growth in vehicular traffic, for example, does not take
into  account  increased  traffic  generated  by  the  completion  of  the  Southern  Provincial  Roads
Improvement  Project  and  the  Southern  Transport  Development  Project.  With  the  successful
completion  of  these  other  projects,  the  overall  impact  of  the  Project  can  be  expected  to  be
substantially greater than shown by the economic analysis.

135.
Finally,  risk  is  associated  with  lack  of  O&M  of  rural  infrastructure,  particularly  roads.
Benefits from this component are dependent upon the upgrading being done properly, especially
for  adequate  compaction  and  drainage;  and  upon  local  governments  implementing  adequate
O&M  regime  on  these  roads.  To  decrease  this  risk,  the  Project  (i)  has  set  up  road  selection
criteria,  (ii)  requires  that  local  governments  sign  a  memorandum  of  understanding  with  the
provincial council to implement adequate maintenance on chosen roads, and (iii) provides TA to
ensure  quality  road  improvement  and  maintenance  regimes,  and  guide  pradeshiya  sabhas  in
revenue generation and budgetary management.

Sri Lanka has a diversified banking system with commercial banks, licensed specialized

B.

  Design Criteria

2.
With  proper  maintenance,  an  unpaved  road  can  provide  a  good  level  of  service  for
traffic.    The  purpose  of  maintenance  is  to  provide  smooth  passage  for  vehicles  by  repairing
damage caused by a combination of weather and traffic.  The first objective of maintenance is to
keep the road in such a condition that it sheds water quickly.  If a road does not shed water, the
surface becomes soft and ruts, potholes will quickly appear.  Under such conditions earth roads
soon become impassable.

3.
Maintenance  to  restore  a  good  camber  to  the  road  to  enable  rapid  drainage  is  best
achieved by regular grading or patching to fill potholes, maintain the shape of the surface, repair
erosion  gullies,  and  restore  displaced  gravel  from  the  shoulders  to  the  main  road  platform.
Patching is the optimum method for general repairs when machinery is not readily available and
requires properly trained workers.

4.
To  minimize  maintenance  activities  and  hence  maintenance  cost  a  well-designed
unpaved  road  is  necessary  in  the  first  place.  This  entails  a  road  with  adequately  compacted
foundation,  subbase,  and  surface  layers;  a  properly  shaped  surface;  properly  sorted  surface
material; and adequate lateral drainage.

The Southern Province Regional Economic Advancement Project (SPREAP) will have a
1.

unemployed  youth;    (iii)  complementing  the  economic  advancement  impact  of  other  Asian

Demand Analysis

1.

Demand for Improving Markets and Access Roads

2.
Rural markets (active one or two days a week) comprise the most important marketing
channel for farm produce in the project area. Most agricultural produce for local consumption is
traded at such markets and wholesale traders catering to urban markets also procure much of
their  fruits  and  vegetables  from  farmers  and  other  traders  at  local  markets.    The  demand  for
better quality vegetables and fruit is strong, both for local consumption and for urban markets.1
Current markets, however, are not really suitable for high-quality produce trade due to their low
sanitation  standard  and  uncovered  and  earthen-floored  facilities.  Traded  produce  is  also
damaged  during  transit  due  to  the  poor  quality  of  local  rural  access  roads.    Quantitative  and
qualitative produce losses incurred in the local marketing chain are estimated at approximately

5.
Gravel rural roads under local authorities (pradeshiya sabhas) are to be selected by the
Project  for  upgrading  into  easily  maintainable  condition.    Selection  criteria  emphasize  the
economic  importance  of  the  roads  to  be  improved,  particularly  their  association  with  rural

road quality plus the retention of that improved condition through timely and appropriate levels
of maintenance.  Through better compaction, the installation of drains, etc., the improved roads
(compared with their original condition) are expected to be within the capacity of the pradeshiya
sabhas to maintain in good condition throughout the project life of 15 years.   Benefits include (i)
decreased  vehicle  operating  cost  (VOC),  estimated  to  decline  from  SLRs9.0/kilometer  (km)  to

speed on the roads increases from 10 km/hr to 15 km/hr; and (iii) a 15 percent decrease in the
amount of spoilage of agricultural produce during transportation to the markets.5  Spoilage and
traffic benefits are calculated in relation to the volume of business generated by the average of

traffic increases are not included in the analysis.
